• Kaliyattam is a popular ritual form of worship in Kerala, India, predominantly in the Kolathunadu area and also in South Canara and Kodagu of Karnataka as a living cult with several thousand-year-old traditions, rituals and customs

• It is performed in house as a form of ancestor worship.
• Kaliyattam has an element of dance, music, drama & mire.

Questions: Which one of the following themes could not be found in the Ashokan inscriptions?
Explanation: The inscriptions and edicts of Asoka refer to a collection of 33 inscriptions on the Pillars of Asoka, as well as boulders and cave walls, made by the Emperor Asoka during his reign from 272 to 231 BC dispersed throughout the areas of modern-day Pakistan, Nepal and India

Questions:
Consider the following statements:
1.Most of the Ashokan inscriptions have been written in Brahmi script.
2.Junagadh inscription of Rudradaman was in chaste Prakrit.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
Explanation: The inscriptions found in the eastern part of India were written in the Magadhi language, using the Brahmi script. In the western part of India, the language used is closer to Sanskrit, using the Kharoshthi script,one extract of Edict 13 in the Greek language.

Questions: Peitra Dura is
Option A: A decorative art made using polished coloured stones.
Option B: A royal weaving pattern mentioned in Akbarnama.
Option C: A handmade decorative blade fitted with gemstones to showcase military victories.
Option D: A miniature paintings of natural colours often found in Mughal Darbars.
Explanation: These are stone carvings in high and low relief on the walls, the delicate carving of marble into jails and graceful volutes (spiral ornament on the pillars), and the creation of arabesque with pietradura on walls and tombstones and geometric designs with tessellation.

Questions:
In the Nagara style of temples
1.Elaborate band of walls or gateway are not constructed.
2.The garbagraha is always located in directly under the tallest tower.
Select the correct answer using the codes given below
Explanation:
1. The Temple complex is not enclosed.
2. The Garbhagriha (Inner Sanctum) is topped by a Shikhara which is curvilinear shaped.
3. Elaborate band of walls or gateway are constructed
4. The Mandapa (main hall) are of different types called as Ardhamandapa, Mandapa and Mahamandapa. Based on their sizes.
5. There is a Stone disc type structure called as amalaka at the top of the Temple.
6. Amalaka is Topped by a Kalasha which is the highest point of the Shikara as well as the entire temple.
7. There is also an Anatarala, which is transition area between the Garbhagriha and the Mandapa.
8. The walls and pillars of the temple are decorated by sculpted images of river goddesses and mithuna images

Questions:
Consider the following statements: 
1. Acharya Virasena was Jain monk and a mathematician during the time of Rashtrakuta.
2. Jainism was source of Virasena and he wrote HarivaPurana.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
Explanation: 1. Acharya Virasena (792-853) was a Digambara monk\n2. Virasena wrote a commentary on Satkhandagama called Dhavala. It contains 72 thousand verses.\n3. Virasena also wrote a commentary on Kasaya-pahuda called Jayadhavala. It is an equally monumental work containing 20 thousand verses written by Virasena to which another 40 thousand were added by his disciple Jinasena.

Questions:
Consider the following statements regarding Tiwa Tribes:
1. They are located in Assam only.
2. They are recognized as STs in Assam.
3. They belong to Tibeto-Burman Race.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
Explanation:
1. Tiwa tribes are indigenous ethnic groups inhabiting the states of Assam and Meghalaya.
2. Plains Tiwas live on the flat lands of the Southern bank of the Brahmaputra valley and influenced wet rice cultivation methods, and rice has become their major crop
3. Tiwa, or Lalung, is a Tibeto-Burman language of Assam in North East India.
4. PanthaiLanga is one of the rituals practised by them, which is meant to worship the deities of nature.
5. Tiwa people who live in the hills are not permitted to prepare their paddy field for the next harvest before performing PanthaiLanga ritual.

Questions:
Consider the following pairs regarding important places associated with Lord Buddha:
1. Lumbini - Birth
2. Rajagir - Last Sermon
3. Vaishali - Met Bimbisara& Ajatashatru
Which of the pairs given above is/are correctly matched?
Explanation: 1. Rajgir was the early capital of MagadhJanapada, which was ruled by Bimbisara during Buddha’s time. After the great departure (Mahabhinishkramana), Buddha had first gone to Rajgir. He started begging alms over there and living life of an ascetic. King Bimbisara had offered Buddha his throne which he turned down.\n2. Vaishali At the time of Buddha, Vaishali was in VajjiJanapada.  After leaving Kapilavastu for renunciation, he came to Vaishali first and had his spiritual training from Allara and Udaka

Questions:
Consider the following statements regarding Kathakali Dance:
1. It is mixture of story and drama.
2. It emphasis on eye & eyebrows movement.
Which of the statemetns given above is/are correct?
Explanation:
1. Kathakali is a classical dance form of Kerala. It derives its name from 'Katha' means story and 'kali' means drama. The fold traditions, Ramanattam and Krishnanattam performed in temples under the patronage of feudal lords became the source of Kathakali.
2. Kathakali declined after the breakdown of the feudal lords. Later renowned Malayali poet Vallathol Narayana Menon revived it under the patronage of Mukunda Raja. He established Kerala Kala Mandalam for the progress of Kathakali.
3. Kathakali is a dance-drama where the actor does not speak their lines.
4. It is performed in open air theatre or in temple premises. Brass lamp is used for lighting.
5. Kathakali depicts the eternal conflict between God and Evil in most of its presentations.
6. Representation of Rasa through movement of Eye and Eyebrows is the most remarkable feature of Kathakali. This needs strenuous training to perform.

Questions:
Consider the following statements.
1. BaqiBillah founded the Naqshbandi order of Sufism in India
2. Mughal emperor Aurangazeb belonged to the Naqshbandi order
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
Explanation:
1. This order was founded by Bahibillah and the followers were very orthodox compared to all other orders.
2. This order was popularized in India by Babur who was deeply devoted to Naqshbandiyya leader KhwajaUbaidullahAhrar.
3. One of the disciples of Khwaja was Shaikh Ahmad Sirhindi who opposed all those practices and beliefs of Akbar and demanded re-imposition of Jizyah
4. Later he was imprisoned by Jahangir for claiming a status beyond that of the Prophet.

Questions: “Punarbhu” – is a term used in ancient India for which among the following?
Option A: A Rig Vedic custom of fraternal polyandry
Option B: A Brahmana woman who had eloped with a shudra man
Option C: A widowed woman marrying a male relative of the deceased husband
Explanation: Punarbhu - A widow who had remarried.

Questions: Which one of the following was not one of the major features to be found in Jahangir’s painting?
Option A: Prevalence of court scenes & animal studies
Explanation:
1. Mughal Emperor Jahangir ruled from 1605 to 1627
2. He stretched great support to several art forms, specifically paintings.
3. This era has seen enhancement in brushwork, along with the usage of much lighter and subdued colors. 
4. The main themes of this era’s paintings were revolved around the events from the life of Jahangir’s, along with portraits, birds, flowers, animals, etc.

Questions: The term ‘yavanika’ meant which of the following in ancient India?
Option A: The reins and saddle of an important horse
Option B: The curtains at the back of the stage in a drama
Option D: The breast plate of an armour
Explanation: The term Yavanika for curtain shows that Indian drama, at least on one point, was influenced by the Greek model

Questions:
Consider the following statements regarding Badami paintings:
1. It belongs to Chalukya dynasty
2. It contains Brahamana religion & Jains
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
Explanation:
1. Badami or Vatapi as it was earlier known as , is one of the most treasured monuments of ancient India. 
2. The paintings which are housed in rock-cut cave temples mostly belong to 6th and 8th centuries. 
3. The caves at Vatapi were fully decorated with murals; many of them were inspired from Puranas. 
4. The most surviving murals include the paintings of Shiva and Parvathi as well as some other characters.
5. The painting style is close with that in Ajanta.
6. The Cave number 4 has a mural painting of Adinatha, the Jain tirthankara.

Questions:
Consider the following statements  regarding Bagha Painting:
1. It is not similar to Ajanta painting
2. It does not use the Prior Plaster Method
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
Explanation:
1. Located on the bank of Baghani river in the Dhar district of Madhya Pradesh
2. The walls and ceilings were to be painted were covered with a thick mud plaster in brownish orange color. 
3. Over this plaster there was done lime-priming and then paintings were laid.
4. This is also known as tempera technique, which refers to use of permanent fast-drying painting medium consisting of colored pigment mixed with a water-soluble binder media.

1. Sarada script is an abugida writing system of the Brahmic family of scripts , developed around 8th century.

4. It was used for writing Sanskrit and Kashmiri

Explanation: Uposatha was a ceremony in which the Buddhist   monk used to confess their sins committed during the rainy season stay i.e. Vasa.

Questions: Which of the following Buddhist postures ispart of the moment of Buddha’s becomingthe enlightened one?
Explanation:
1. Varadamudra: posture of granting a wish
2. Abhaymudra: posture of fearlessness with right hand raised above shoulder and left hand placed on thigh.
3. Bhumisparshamudra: posture where the Buddha touches the ground/earth with his right hand, indicating the earth as witness of his enlightenment.
4. Dharmachakrapravaran mudra: posture of giving first sermon by using both hands as if rotating something i.e. wheel of law.

Questions:
Consider the following statements regarding associated with Jainism:
1. Cosmic rise and fall is the will of a supremebeing, is one of the cardinal principles ofJainism.
2. Strict adherence to the Five Principles is necessary for all.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
Explanation: 1) According to Jainism the world moves according to a Universal Principle, no supreme entity governs it. But it is not part of Cardinal Principles.\n2) Those who are monks, have to follow the principles, strictly. However, these are a bit relaxed for lay followers and in their context, these as called Anuvrata.

Questions:
Which of the following subjects part of Tamil texts of Sangam Age?
1. Urban trading centers.
2. Social divisions
3. Grammar
4. Military exploits of kings
5. Cult of ideal woman
Select the correct answer using the codes given below
Explanation: 1. The tamil literature deals with the social divisions, crafts, urban centres like Muziris, KaveriPatnam, Arikamedu etc. which traded with Romans.\n2. Tolkapiyyam deals with tamil grammar. The tamil poetry also contains the achievements of kings/warriors in the form of Puram poetry.\n3. The epic Silpadigaram deals with the Kannagi cult i.e. the cult of chaste/ideal woman in South Indian society.

Questions:

Explanation: PuriJaganath Temple belongs to The Shree Jagannath Temple of Puri is an important Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Jagannath, a form of lord Maha Vishnu , located on the eastern coast of India, at Puri in the state of Odisha. \n The temple is an important pilgrimage destination The present temple was rebuilt from the 10th century onwards, on the site of an earlier temple, and begun by King AnantavarmanChodaganga Deva, first of the Eastern Ganga dynasty

Questions: ‘Kalilah-w-Dimna’ was an Arabic version of
Explanation:
• The Panchatantra is an ancient Indian collection of interrelated animal fables in Sanskrit verse and prose, arranged within a frame story.
• The surviving work is dated to about 300 BCE, but the literature is thousands of years older. 
• The text's author is unknown, but has been attributed to Vishnu Sharma in some recensions and Vasubhaga in others, both of which may be pen names.
• It is classical literature in a Hindu text, and based on older oral traditions with animal parables that are as old as we are able to imagine.

Questions: In the context of Sultanate culture, the term‘Arabesque’ can be best described as
Explanation: The arabesque is a form of artistic decoration consisting of 'surface decorations based on rhythmic linear patterns of scrolling and interlacing foliage, tendrils' or plain lines, often combined with other elements.

Questions:
Consider the following statements regarding Medieval Period of Indian history.
1. The period witnessed inter-mingling ofdifferent cultures.
2. Due to overall emphasis on Persian as statelanguage, the regional Indian languagescould not see any progress.
3. For most of the Mughal period, South Indiaremained outside their rule
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
Explanation: 1. Due to advent of Turkish, Afghan and Mughal rulers, there was witnessed gradual emergence of IndoIslamic culture based on blend of both, Indian and Persian.\n2. The regional languages could very well attain literary merit. Bangla, Marathi, Odia, Gujarati, Hindi, Malyalam, Telugu, Kannada etc. could see a vast literature written during medieval age.\n3. However, South India, remained outside direct Mughal control for most of the time and same was the case during sultanate period as well.

Questions:
Consider the following statements regarding features of MughalPaintings:
1. It was more courtly and aristocratic inthemes.
2. It was developed in the time of Akbar due toefforts of Portuguese priests.
3. It was developed as a blend of Indian,Persian and European features.
4. It was developed under the monitoring ofstate department.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
Explanation:
1. Mughal School of painting was started by Humayun with the help of Persian painters brought by him from Iran. 
2. It was given attention by Akbar by establishing an imperial department for it.
3. Most of the Themes of the paintings are related to royal life, depiction of nature, birds, Animals. 
4. Public life is not usually shown.
5. It was also influenced by the European features.

Questions:
Consider the following statements:
1. A typical Mughal painting was produced bythe efforts of several painters.
2. Emperor Jehangir could discriminate thework of each artist.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
Explanation: 1. Mughal painting reached a climax under Jahangir who had a very discriminating eye.\n2. It was a fashion in the Mughal school for the faces, bodies and feet of the people in a single picture to be painted by different artists.\n3. Jahangir claims that he could distinguish the work of each artist in a picture

Questions: In the context of medieval age culture, theterm Sutradhara, can be best described as
Option A: One who supervised construction of temples
Option B: One who narrated Puranic stories to villagemen
Option C: One who headed the priesthood in a temple
Explanation: 1. The construction of temples was supervised by the sutradharas. Manuals on construction – the shilpashastra – were used where large temples were constructed.\n2. To follow the established norms of temple building required the supervision of a sutradhara and a manual. Sutradharas were being named in inscriptions

Questions:
Consider the following pairs regarding  folk arts with their regions:
1. Dhokra  : Chhattisgarh
2. Ajrakh : Rajasthan
3. Patachitra : Jammu & Kashmir
4. Phad paintings : Maharashtra
Which of the pairs given above is/are correctly matched?
Explanation: 1. Dhokra (also spelt Dokra) is non–ferrous metal casting using the lost-wax casting technique. DhokraDamar tribes are the traditional metalsmiths of West Bengal and Odisha. \n2. Their technique of lost wax casting is named after their tribe, hence Dhokra metal casting. The tribe extends from Jharkhand to West Bengal and Orissa; members are distant cousins of the Chhattisgarh Dhokras. Ajrakh is a cloth art of Gujarat and Rajasthan

Questions:
Consider the following statements:
1. Sattriya dance has devotional character,inspired by Bhakti movement in Assam.
2. The Dance is mainly performed by malemonks.
3. It is based on Shaiva bhakti
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
Explanation: 1. Recognised most recently in 2000. It is devotional in character and involves Bhakti Rasa (spiritual aspect), Evolved by a great Vaishnava saint Shankar dev in 15th century. \n2. Traditionally danceperformed by male monks called Bhokots in monasteries as a part of their daily rituals, calledSattriya as monasteries called Sattras.\n3. This dance isaccompanied by a Musical composition calledBorgeets. This was composed by Shankar Devmusical instruments- khol (drum), and flute

Questions:
Consider the following books written by Indian rulers
1. Mattavilasaprahsana : Tamil
2. Amuktamalyada : Telegu
3. Kavirajamarga : Sanskrit
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
Explanation:
• MattavilasaPrahasana is a short one-act Sanskrit play.
• It is one of the two great one act plays written by Pallava King Mahendravarman I (571– 630CE) in the beginning of the seventh century in Tamil Nadu.
• Kavirajamarga is the earliest available work on rhetoric, poetics and grammar in the Kannada language. 
• It was inspired by or written in part by the famous Rashtrakuta King Amoghavarsha I, and some historians claim it is based partly on an the Sanskrit text Kavyadarsha.
